title: 103_hr624
content: The Act is titled the "National Commemorative Events Advisory Act" and includes findings. The Act titled the "National Commemorative Events Advisory Act" finds that a commission should be established to efficiently review proposals for national commemorative events, saving time and resources for Congress to focus on more pressing national concerns. Reviewing proposals for national commemorative events from various constituent groups. SEC. 3. ESTABLISHMENT AND MEMBERSHIP. The President's Advisory Commission on National Commemorative Events is established with 11 members appointed by the Speaker of the House, President pro tempore of the Senate, and the President, representing diverse backgrounds. Members serve 2-year terms and must be U.S. citizens. The President's Advisory Commission on National Commemorative Events has 11 members appointed by various officials for 2-year terms. Vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment, and the Chairman is designated. Members appointed as Members of Congress can continue for up to 30 days after leaving office. The Chairman of the Commission is designated by the President from among the members for a 2-year term. 6 members constitute a quorum for issuing recommendations. The Commission meets quarterly in Washington, D.C. Members are paid the daily equivalent of GS-15 pay, except for full-time government employees or Members of Congress. Members of the Commission are entitled to additional pay for their service. They are also allowed travel expenses, including a per diem allowance, while performing Commission duties away from their homes or regular places of business. The Commission has the authority to appoint a Director and staff, who may be appointed and paid without following certain civil service laws. Federal agencies can also provide personnel to assist the Commission upon request. The Commission has the authority to hold hearings, accept gifts, use the United States mails, and receive administrative support services. The Commission is responsible for establishing criteria for recommending national commemorative events to the President, reviewing proposals, and issuing recommendations with explanations for approval or disapproval. The effective date and provisions for commencement and termination are also outlined. SEC. 7 of the Act states that it will take effect at the beginning of the One Hundred Third Congress. The Commission must be appointed and hold its first meeting within 90 days of the Act's effective date. The Commission will be terminated 5 years after its first meeting.
